movies.name: joker
movies.text: Arthur Fleck, a clown and aspiring stand-up comedian, lives with his mother, Penny, in crime-ridden�Gotham City. Arthur suffers from a neurological disorder that causes him to have random, uncontrollable laughing fits, requiring medication for which he depends on social services. After Arthur is attacked by juvenile delinquents, his co-worker Randall gives him a revolver for self-defense. Arthur pursues a relationship with his neighbor, single mother Sophie, and invites her to see his routine at a comedy club. Arthur is fired from his job at a children's hospital when he accidentally exposes the gun despite his explanation that it was given to him by Randall, who denies this. While riding home on the subway still wearing his clown makeup, Arthur is mocked and beaten by drunk businessmen from Wayne Investments; he fatally shoots two of them in self-defense and murders the third as he attempts to flee. The killings are condemned by their employer, billionaire mayoral candidate Thomas Wayne. Protesters begin donning clown masks in Arthur's image. Budget cuts shut down the social service program, leaving Arthur without his medication.
movies.review1: Not only an intelligent throwback to the feel-bad shock cinema of the 1970s, Joker is all but unique in its social realism...
movies.review2: The result of these creative decisions, however, is that whatever power Joker, as a pop culture icon, might wield, Joker, as a movie, feels toothless.
movies.review3: Joker is a jumble - sometimes brilliant and sometimes trite. Among its flashes of excellence is a self-serious movie that isn't nearly as deep as it thinks it is.

movies.name: 12 angry man
movies.text: In the sweltering jury room of the�New York County Courthouse, a jury prepares to deliberate the case of an impoverished teenager accused of stabbing his abusive father to death. The judge instructs the Jury that if there is any�reasonable doubt, the jurors are to return a verdict of not guilty; if found guilty, the defendant will receive a mandatory death sentence via the�electric chair. The verdict must be unanimous.
movies.review1: This movie is a masterpiece. That term gets thrown around a lot -- it's a very easy thing to say about great films like this -- but this movie is one of the best.
movies.review2: The film takes a confined, almost completely banal real-world location and makes it completely dynamic.
movies.review3: Mechanically written, but within its own middlebrow limitations, it delivers the goods.

movies.name: predestination
movies.text: In March 1975, an agent stops a bombing of a public building in New York City, but is caught in a gunfight, containing the bomb too late and suffering severe burns. Someone unseen helps him grasp his time-travel device, which he uses to retreat to his employer's facility in 1992. The agent considers his mission a failure because the "Fizzle Bomber," the unidentified serial-bombing fugitive he confronted, remains at large and will carry out his bombing on another day, ultimately killing over ten thousand.
movies.review1: One of Ethan Hawke's strengths as an actor is his willingness to jump between arthouse fare and B-movie genre fodder.
movies.review2: A funny, affecting, twisted tale, which demands you pay close attention to every throwaway detail.
movies.review3: The most interesting time-travel movie since Primer.

movies.name: ford v ferrari
movies.text: In 1963,�Ford Motor Company�Vice President�Lee Iacocca�proposes to�Henry Ford II�to boost their car sales by purchasing Italian car manufacturer�Ferrari, dominant in the�24 Hours of Le Mans. Owner�Enzo Ferrari�uses Ford's offer to secure a deal with�Fiat�that allows him to retain ownership of the firm's racing team,�Scuderia Ferrari. He insults Ford II and the whole Ford Motor Company. Ford orders his racing division to build a car to defeat Ferrari at Le Mans. Iacocca hires�Shelby American�owner�Carroll Shelby, a retired driver who won�Le Mans in 1959. Shelby enlists his friend�Ken Miles, a hot-tempered British racer and mechanical engineer.
movies.review1: You see the concentration. You see the sweat. You see the danger. You see the madness.
movies.review2: Ford v Ferrari is a little too long; some scenes leave unnecessary skidmark trails. But the movie still has amiable style and energy to spare.
movies.review3: It is a beautifully controlled and assembled piece of filmmaking.

movies.name: Million Dollar Baby
movies.text: Margaret "Maggie" Fitzgerald, a waitress from the�Ozarks, shows up at the Hit Pit, a rundown�Los Angeles�gym owned and operated by Frankie Dunn. Dunn is a cantankerous�Irish-American�trainer, revealed to be estranged from his own daughter. Maggie asks Frankie to train her, but he refuses as he does not train women and she is too old to begin a boxing career. Eddie "Scrap-Iron" Dupris, Frankie's friend and employee�the film's narrator�encourages and helps Maggie. Frankie's prize prospect, "Big Willie" Little, signs with successful manager Mickey Mack after becoming impatient with Frankie rejecting offers for a championship bout. Frankie then reluctantly agrees to train Maggie.
movies.review1: Anyone who doesn't believe that Clint Eastwood is one of the best film-makers in America ought to see Million Dollar Baby.
movies.review2: Million Dollar Baby is as close to an anti-Rocky as a sports picture ever came, but even when following familiar paths, it stakes out its own distinctively harsh territory.
movies.review3: Age has clenched Clint Eastwood's face tight as a fist, but he has never been more tender, vulnerable, and heartbroken than in Million Dollar Baby.

movies.name: dunkirk
movies.text: In 1940, during the�Battle of France,�Allied�soldiers have retreated to�Dunkirk. Tommy Jensen, a young British private, is the sole survivor of a�German�ambush. At the beach, he finds thousands of troops awaiting evacuation and meets Gibson, an aloof soldier who is burying a body. After a�Luftwaffe�dive bomber�attack, they attempt to get aboard a hospital ship but are ordered off. The ship is sunk by dive bombers; Tommy saves another soldier, named Alex.
movies.review1: The visuals, the structure, the use of sound and music, and the simple presence of a beating heart - all come together in a whole that is truly breathtaking.
movies.review2: Dunkirk shows off Nolan's own techniques as a filmmaker to make for a film that is technically, if not completely narratively, lustrous.
movies.review3: When Dunkirk ended, I realized it wasn't Dunkirk I wanted to watch: It was the sequel.

movies.name: Miracle in Cell No.�7
movies.text: In 2004, an upcoming bride becomes emotional as news comes out that�capital punishment in Turkey�has been abolished. The story then moves to a flashback to a village in 1983. A�mentally impaired�father, Mehmet "Memo" Koyuncu, lives with his young daughter, Ova, and his grandmother on a hillside. On a visit to the town, he figures in a slight altercation with the daughter of a local military officer over a bag that Ova also wants. Later, while wandering in the hills, Memo meets the officer's daughter, who offers the bag if he could catch her. However, the girl accidentally dies after falling off a cliff, and Memo's attempts to save her are misunderstood to be an act of murder and he is sent to prison but not before he tells Ova that he saw a witness to what really happened. In prison, he is speedily convicted of murder and sentenced to death, and is beaten up by fellow inmates who are unaware of the true circumstances of his case.
movies.review2: You'll Laugh. You'll Cry. You'll Care. You'll Love. And You'll Have A Great Time.
movies.review3: A story that made me cry and i'm a cold hearted person
